text: [Music]
hello I'm Philip Griffin I'm northa I
write fiction and nonfiction and my
latest book is may we borrow your
language
what makes swear words offensive is that
people are ready to be offended by them
it's almost as if society as a whole
takes a kind of conscious or actually
unconscious decision to say this word is
taboo while other words are not
offensive and things change actually
quite quickly if you think back to 30 or
40 years ago the kind of language that
you can fairly regularly hear on
television now and certainly you know in
the cinema is quite standard it's
available and accessible to pretty well
anybody but there would have been a
fantastic fuss about some of these terms
three or four decades back it's almost
as if in language that there has to be a
part of language which is a kind of
rather dark and sinister area where
people are wary about treading but at
the same time they want to go though
many people want to go there one word
that was considered really offensive a
hundred years ago was the word body and
when the playwright George Bernard Shaw
used it I think in 1913 at the premiere
of Pygmalion the audience reaction was
hysterical and Bernard Shaw wrote to a
friend he thought the performance would
have to be stopped because the audience
was so loud
and this was on the single word bloody I
think eliza doolittle it says not bloody
like and the audience can collapse but
can you imagine anybody doing that now
or even raising an eyebrow eyebrow are
the word bloody in fact 'you don't hear
it much now
